questions.subject: English
questions.question: The webpage begins with the heading "Calling Youth With A Vision"! What effect is the phrase "With A Vision" intended to have on young readers?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Look at the photograph at the bottom of the webpage. With reference to the section "Who joins YSEALI?", what idea does the photograph convey about why people join YSEALI?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: From the section "What is YSEALI?", state the two main aims of the organisation.

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Which sentence summarises the main aim of the webpage?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: At the beginning of this text there is a description of the lean appearance of the wolves which were following Henry. Explain how the language used in paragraph 1 emphasises their leanness. Support your ideas with three details from paragraph 1.

questions.subject: English
questions.question: In paragraph 1 the writer refers to the lack of light as the 'gloom'. Identify two seperate words used later in the paragraph which also describe the light.

questions.subject: English
questions.question: 'With the night came horror. Not only were the famished wolves growing bolder, but Henry was tired' (lines 9-10) What effect does the writer create by using a short sentence followed by a longer one?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: The writer tells us 'With the night came horror.' Explain in your own words what was happening.

questions.subject: English
questions.question: The wolf was 'looking upon him with the arrogance of possession' (line 12). Which two things did the wolf do that clearly indicated she thought she owned Henry?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: In paragraph 2, the writer tells us that the wolves looked 'like children gathered round a spread table, waiting to eat'. What does the 'spread table' refer to?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: In paragraph 3, what was unusual about the wolves' behaviour?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: In paragraph 4, Henry builds a 'shelter of flame'. What two things does he do?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: What did he hope would happen because he had a 'shelter of flame'?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Give two reasons why henry said, 'I guess you can come and get me any time now' (lines 30-31)

questions.subject: English
questions.question: In paragraph 5, what 'mysterious change had taken place'?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: the structure of the text reflects the staves in henry's experience with the wolves. Complete the flow chart by choosing one phrase from the box to summarise the events in each stage. There are some extra phrases in the box you do not need to use

questions.subject: English
questions.question: (a) In the first sentence, the writer uses the phrase 'the world's car-obsessed inhabitants'. What is the writer's attitude towards the car owners of today? (b) Which word in the next sentence reinforces this attitude?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: From lines 66-7, what kind of track do you think was needed for driving cars?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: What types of accidents do you think happened to carts which were driven on (i) 'steep and rocky" tracks and (ii)( 'low-lying and boggy' tracks (lines 7-8)?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Explain in your own words why the main streets within towns were often paved with stone (lines 9-10).

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Why does the writer refer to pollution as an 'insidious' side effect (line 41)?

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Identify one example from paragraph 4 that Su Lin can give to support her view.

questions.subject: English
questions.question: How would ahmed explain his position with reference to lines 45-48? Give two points.

questions.subject: English
questions.question: Using your own words as far as possible, summarise the challenges that road builders have faced and the improvements they have made to overcome each of them, during the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.
